<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=19,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=971748,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DI1223A.;14',USER='KLIND',CD='18-MAR-2003;14:24' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dk1223_1_20"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1223_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1223_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Overview  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Northwest Airlines Corporation ("NWA Corp.") is a holding company whose principal indirect operating subsidiary is Northwest Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. ("Northwest").
The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of NWA Corp. and all consolidated subsidiaries (collectively, the "Company"). The Company reported a net loss of $798&nbsp;million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, compared with a net loss of $423&nbsp;million in 2001. Loss per common share was $9.32 in 2002 compared with loss per common share of $5.03 in 2001. Operating
loss was $846&nbsp;million in 2002 compared with operating loss of $868&nbsp;million in 2001. Operating revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 decreased by $416&nbsp;million
compared to 2001 primarily due to a decline in business travel caused by an economic slowdown in the United States, weakness in the Asian economies and reduced demand for travel resulting from the
September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Full
year 2002 results included $464&nbsp;million in unusual pre-tax charges, principally comprised of $352&nbsp;million attributable to the accelerated retirement of
certain Boeing 747-200 and DC10-30 aircraft, $53&nbsp;million of costs associated with the closure of several facilities, $32&nbsp;million related to benefit costs and
other asset write-downs, and a $27&nbsp;million partial write-down of the Company's receivable from the U.S. Government related to the grant under the Air Transportation Safety and
System Stabilization Act ("Airline Stabilization Act"). In addition, the effective tax rate reflected a provision of $15&nbsp;million for tax credits the Company expects to expire unused. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Full
year 2001 results included $300&nbsp;million in unusual pre-tax charges related to $161&nbsp;million of reductions in the estimated market values of aircraft,
$89&nbsp;million retroactive wages and benefits as a result of labor contract settlements, $27&nbsp;million of employee severance costs following the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and
$23&nbsp;million in other non-operating charges. These charges were offset by $461&nbsp;million of grant income from the U.S. government under the Airline Stabilization Act and a
$27&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's investment in Continental Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially
all of the Company's results of operations are attributable to its principal indirect operating subsidiary, Northwest, which accounted for approximately 95% of the
Company's 2002 consolidated operating revenues and expenses. The Company's results of operations also include other subsidiaries, of which MLT&nbsp;Inc. ("MLT") and Pinnacle Airlines,&nbsp;Inc.
("Pinnacle Airlines") are the most significant. The following discussion pertains primarily to Northwest and, where indicated, MLT and Pinnacle Airlines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Northwest and Airline Industry Current Status  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The current U.S. airline industry environment is the worst in history. Since early 2001, the U.S. airline industry has suffered a significant decline in revenues
versus what would have been expected based on historical growth trends. This shortfall has been caused by a number of factors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
rapid growth of low cost airlines has had a profound impact on industry revenues. Using the advantage of low unit costs, these carriers offer lower fares, particularly those targeted
at business passengers, in order to shift demand from larger, more-established airlines. As a result of growth, these low cost carriers now transport nearly 25% of all domestic U.S. passengers
compared to less than 10% a decade ago. They now compete for, and thus influence industry pricing on, approximately 75% of all domestic U.S. passenger ticket sales compared to less than 20% a decade
ago. As a result of their better financial performance, low cost carriers are expected to continue to grow their market share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
the advent of Internet travel Web sites has driven significant distribution cost savings for airlines, it has had a large negative impact on airline revenues. Having access to
"perfect pricing information", air travel consumers have become more efficient at finding lower fare alternatives than in </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=20,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=586353,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223A.;17',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_21"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
the past. The increased price consciousness of travelers, as well as the proliferation of distribution channels, has further motivated airlines to price more aggressively to gain fare advantages
through certain channels. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
U.S. airline industry is one of the most heavily taxed of all industries. Taxes and fees now represent approximately 25% of what a passenger pays for an average domestic airline
ticket, a percentage even greater than that for alcohol and tobacco products. These taxes and fees have grown significantly in the past decade, most recently with the introduction of a $2.50 security
fee imposed on each passenger flight segment, subject to a $10 per roundtrip cap. The company believes that every dollar of tax or fee increase imposed on airline passengers roughly translates into a
dollar of reduced airline revenue, particularly over the long run. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
attacks of September 11, 2001 materially impacted and continue to impact air travel. Concerns about further terrorist attacks, which are unlikely to abate any time soon, have had a
negative impact on air travel demand. Furthermore, security procedures introduced at airports since the attacks have
increased, both in reality and in perception, the inconvenience of flying and thus further reduced demand. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
the factors noted are believed to be lasting, if not permanent, and could in fact worsen over time, some of the current airline industry revenue shortfall is believed to be
cyclical in nature. U.S. airline revenues have historically been and continue to be influenced by the strength of the U.S. economy. Furthermore, airline business revenues are greatly influenced by the
growth in corporate profitability. The current sluggishness of both the economy and corporate profitability is adversely affecting airline revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
airline industry revenue decline has been further exacerbated in early 2003. In January, United Airlines introduced a new pricing structure, reducing its highest business fares by
40-50%. This action and the resulting match by other airlines has reduced average fares without a corresponding increase in demand. The threat of a war with Iraq has also materially affected future
airline bookings, particularly for international travel. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the impact on industry revenue, the September 11, 2001 events caused a significant rise in certain operating costs, particularly for aviation and property insurance. Total
aviation and property insurance expense nearly tripled in 2002, to $121 million. These costs could rise further should coverage presently provided by the government under the Homeland Security Act,
which has been extended until August 31, 2003, no longer be available. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the past year, two major U.S. airlines, US Airways, Inc. and United Air Lines, Inc., have filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Current trends make it likely that the
airline industry will continue to post significant losses, at least through 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
response to the industry environment, the Company has taken several steps to mitigate the impact on its results of operations and financial condition. These steps included a
significant reduction in scheduled capacity on an available seat mile basis, a reduction in work force of 12,000 employees, deferral of certain aircraft orders previously scheduled for delivery in
2003 through 2005 for an average of two years, closure of maintenance facilities, flight crew bases, reservations and sales facilities and deferrals and cancellations of discretionary and other
non-operationally critical spending. For the year ended December 31, 2002, capacity was 9.6% below 2000 levels. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
the Company has already taken these significant cost reduction steps, it believes additional measures will be necessary in this new and permanently changed revenue environment.
Wages, salaries and benefits made up 41% of the Company's 2002 operating revenues and will need to be a major component of future cost reduction initiatives. The Company has begun discussions with its
labor unions in an effort to align wages, benefits and work rules with the new revenue environment and to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=21,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=127963,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223A.;17',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_22"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
remain competitive with those airlines achieving permanent cost reductions through bankruptcy proceedings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations&#151;2002 Compared to 2001  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating revenues decreased 4.2% ($416&nbsp;million). System passenger revenues decreased 5.7%
($466&nbsp;million), excluding Northwest's wholly owned regional carrier affiliate Pinnacle Airlines. The decrease in system passenger revenues was primarily attributable to a 1.5% decrease in
traffic and a 4.3% decline in yields. System passenger load factor increased 2.8 points to 77.1% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. Pinnacle Airlines passenger revenues, net of intercompany
eliminations, increased 36.9% ($73&nbsp;million) to $271&nbsp;million due to increased capacity from 21 Bombardier Canadian Regional Jet ("CRJ") aircraft added in 2002 and higher rates under a new
airline services agreement with Northwest that was effective March&nbsp;1, 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following analysis by market is based on information reported to the U.S. Department of Transportation ("DOT") and excludes Pinnacle Airlines: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Domestic
passenger revenues decreased primarily due to lower yields and capacity, partially offset by a higher passenger load factor. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pacific
passenger revenues decreased due to lower yields and capacity, partially offset by a higher load factor. Capacity was reduced as a result of the September&nbsp;11, 2001
terrorist attacks and yields were lower due to weakness in the Asian economies and a decline in the relative value of the Japanese yen. The average yen per U.S. dollar exchange rates for the years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001 were 126 and 121, respectively, a 4.2% weakening in the buying power of the yen. Additional information regarding the Company's yen exposure and currency
hedging activities is provided in "Item&nbsp;7a. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk". </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Atlantic
passenger revenues were effectively flat, as higher load factors and slightly improved yields were mostly offset by a reduction in capacity. Capacity was reduced as a result of
the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks and weakened U.S. and international economies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo
revenues increased 2.1% ($15&nbsp;million) to $735&nbsp;million due to a 2.8% increase in cargo ton miles partially offset by a 0.6% decline in revenue per ton mile. Cargo
revenues consist of freight and mail carried on passenger aircraft and the Company's 12 747-200F dedicated freighters. Freight revenue increased 7.4% ($46&nbsp;million), including a
benefit of approximately $27&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter resulting from the west coast dockworkers' lockout. However, the freight revenue increase was partially offset by a 29.6%
($31&nbsp;million) decrease in mail revenue due largely to lower volume from U.S. Government restrictions on transportation of packages larger than 16 ounces on passenger aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=22,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=930131,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223A.;17',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_23"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenues, the principal components of which are MLT (a wholly-owned subsidiary), other transportation fees and charter revenues, decreased 5.1% ($39&nbsp;million). This decline
was primarily due to reduced revenues from MLT, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ("KLM") joint venture settlements, ticketing and handling fees and support services, partially offset by an increase in
frequent flyer program partnership revenue. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses decreased 4.1% ($438&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents operating expenses for the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 and describes significant variances from the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2001: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="18%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>10,335</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>(438</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>(4.1</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>)%</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>A.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Salaries,
wages and benefits decreased primarily due to 10.6% fewer full-time equivalent employees and $89&nbsp;million for retroactive wages and benefits related to the
2001 Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association ("AMFA") collective bargaining agreement. This decline was partially offset by higher average wage rates, pension, group insurance, and other
postemployment benefit expenses. Pension expenses increased largely due to a lower actuarial discount rate, a decline in pension asset returns and increased benefits from the 2001 AMFA contract.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>B.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
fuel and taxes were lower due to a 12.5% decrease in the average fuel cost per gallon to 69.33&nbsp;cents, net of hedging transactions, 6.6% fewer fuel gallons consumed as a
result of reduced capacity and the use of more fuel efficient aircraft. Fuel hedge transactions reduced fuel costs by $55&nbsp;million in 2002 and had an immaterial effect in 2001.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>C.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation
and amortization increased primarily due to $372&nbsp;million of aircraft and related parts write-downs recorded in 2002, offset by similar charges of
$161&nbsp;million recorded in the third and fourth quarters of 2001. The increase in depreciation and amortization was partially offset by the elimination of $24&nbsp;million per year from
international route and goodwill amortization recorded prior to 2002. See Note&nbsp;1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional discussion of the fleet disposition charges and
international routes and goodwill no longer being amortized.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>D.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Selling
and marketing (consisting of commissions, credit card fees, computer reservation system fees, advertising and promotion expenses) decreased $109&nbsp;million due primarily to
the elimination of North American base commissions in the second quarter of 2002 and $40&nbsp;million due to lower revenues system wide.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>E.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
maintenance materials and repairs decreased due to lower repair volume in 2002, which resulted from retirements and removal from service of older aircraft, as well as a higher
level of scheduled work within the routine engine and airframe maintenance cycle in 2001. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=23,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=49393,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223A.;17',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_24"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>F.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
rentals and landing fees increased primarily due to the new Detroit Midfield facility, as well as higher rates across the system due to unfunded Transportation Security
Administration ("TSA") mandates.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>G.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
rentals increased due to additional leased aircraft, partially offset by lower variable rates on existing leases.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>H.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
expenses (the principal components of which include outside services, insurance, passenger food, personnel expenses, communication expenses and supplies) decreased principally
due to lower personnel, supplies and claims expenses and reduced levels of passenger food service, partially offset by significantly higher insurance costs. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income and Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other non-operating income decreased by $572&nbsp;million, primarily due to
$461&nbsp;million recognized in 2001 under the Airline Stabilization Act, higher 2002 interest expense related to increased debt levels, and lower interest income as a result of lower interest
rates. In the fourth quarter of 2002, the Company recorded a $27&nbsp;million charge to write-down a portion of a receivable from the U.S. Government to reflect the final amount received
in January&nbsp;2003 under the Airline Stabilization Act. Interest expense increased 15.7% ($58&nbsp;million) primarily due to the full year 2002 borrowings under the Company's revolving credit
facilities and additional new financings. Higher
earnings from affiliates during 2002 were partially offset by a $27&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's remaining shares of Continental recorded in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tax Expense (Benefit).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The tax benefit recorded in 2002 includes a provision of $15&nbsp;million for tax credits that are
expected to expire unused. The Company's net deferred tax liability declined from $843&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001 to $30&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002, primarily due to
the increase in deferred tax assets relating to the Company's pension plans and the Company's 2002 losses. Given its recent loss experience, current accounting rules do not allow its balance sheet to
reflect a net tax asset position. As a result, when future losses generate deferred tax assets that fully offset the Company's deferred tax liabilities, no further tax benefit may be recognized with
respect to those losses. The Company expects that approximately $80&nbsp;million of losses in 2003 will yield tax benefits capable of being recognized. Consequently, pre-tax losses above
$80&nbsp;million are not expected to be reduced by the recognition of future tax benefits associated with such losses. See Note&nbsp;9 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional
discussion of the Company's tax accounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations&#151;2001 Compared to 2000  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating revenues decreased 11.9% ($1.34&nbsp;billion). System passenger revenues decreased 13.7%
($1.30&nbsp;billion), excluding Pinnacle Airlines. The decrease in system passenger revenues was primarily attributable to a 4.8% decrease in scheduled service ASMs&nbsp;and a 9.2% decrease in
passenger RASM. System passenger load factor decreased 2.3 points to 74.3% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Pinnacle Airlines passenger revenues increased 52.3% ($68&nbsp;million) to
$198&nbsp;million due to increased capacity resulting from 21 additional Bombardier CRJ 200 series aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>)%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Domestic
passenger revenues decreased due to lower yields, passenger load factor and capacity. Northwest experienced a decline in business and leisure travel due to the impact of the
slowing U.S. economy and the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001. Approximately 78% of the decrease in domestic passenger revenues occurred between September&nbsp;1 and December&nbsp;31, 2001. In
response to the decline in demand for air travel after the terrorist attacks, domestic fourth quarter capacity was reduced 14.7%, as compared to 2000, on an ASM basis. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pacific
passenger revenues decreased due to lower yields, passenger load factor and capacity. Approximately 64% of the decrease in Pacific passenger revenues occurred between
September&nbsp;1 and December&nbsp;31, 2001. In response to the reduced demand for air travel, Pacific fourth quarter capacity was reduced 19.5%, as compared to 2000, on an ASM basis. The
introduction of a reconfigured World Business Class product, which improved seat pitch from 48 inches to 60 inches and replaced international first class, also contributed to the reduced capacity.
Passenger load factor and yields were also impacted by the slowing Asian economies and a weakened Japanese yen. The average yen per U.S. dollar exchange rates for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2001 and 2000 were 121 and 107, respectively, an 11.2% weakening in the buying power of the yen. Additional information regarding the Company's yen exposure and currency hedging activities is provided
in "Item 7a. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk". </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Atlantic
passenger revenues decreased due to a decline in yields and passenger load factor resulting from the terrorist attacks on September&nbsp;11, 2001. In response to the reduced
demand for air travel, Atlantic fourth quarter capacity was reduced 14.3%, as compared to 2000, on an ASM basis. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo
revenues decreased 16.0% ($137&nbsp;million) to $720&nbsp;million due to a 2.8% decline in revenue per ton mile and 13.6% fewer cargo ton miles. These decreases resulted
primarily from reduced U.S. demand for Asian goods caused by the slowing U.S. economy, the weakened yen per U.S. dollar exchange rate, and a decline in total cargo space on passenger aircraft as a
result of the reduction in system passenger capacity. Service began in July&nbsp;2001 under a new five-year agreement with DHL Worldwide Express to provide daily freighter service from
its U.S. hub operations in Cincinnati to various points in Asia. The Company's eleventh and twelfth freighters were placed in revenue service to support this agreement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenues (the principal components of which are MLT, other transportation fees and charter revenues) increased 5.2% ($38&nbsp;million) primarily due to higher charter revenues
and other transportation fees. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_26"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses increased 1.0% ($102&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents operating expenses for the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2001 and describes significant variances from the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2000: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>A.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Salaries,
wages and benefits increased primarily due to higher wages and benefits from settled contracts with collective bargaining units, retroactive wages and benefits of
$89&nbsp;million related to the 2001 AMFA agreement and higher pension, group insurance, and other post-employment benefits expenses.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>B.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
fuel and taxes declined due to a decrease of 4.5% in average fuel cost per gallon to 79.26&nbsp;cents, net of hedging transactions, and 4.0% fewer fuel gallons consumed as a
result of the reduced capacity.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>C.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation
and amortization increased primarily due to charges of $161&nbsp;million related to the reductions in the estimated market values of aircraft recorded in the third and
fourth quarters of 2001, partially offset by $125&nbsp;million of DC10 impairments recorded in 2000. See Note&nbsp;1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional discussion of the fleet
disposition charges.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>D.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Selling
and marketing (consisting of commissions, credit card fees, computer reservation system fees, advertising and promotion expenses) decreased primarily due to lower passenger
revenues, use of lower cost distribution channels and a decline in the percentage of commissionable transactions. Internet sales, which typically have lower commission rates than other distribution
channels, represented approximately 13% of passenger revenues in 2001 compared with approximately 8.0% in 2000.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>E.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
maintenance materials and repairs increased due to a higher level of scheduled work within the routine engine and airframe maintenance cycle.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>F.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
rentals increased due to additional leased aircraft.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>G.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
expenses (the principal components of which include outside services, insurance, passenger food, personnel expenses, communication expenses and supplies) decreased principally
due to lower variable costs associated with reduced capacity and a favorable foreign currency impact on expenses, partially offset by higher insurance costs following the September&nbsp;11, 2001
terrorist attacks. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income and Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recognized $461&nbsp;million of grant income from the U.S. Government under the
Airline Stabilization Act in 2001. Interest expense increased 5.4% ($19&nbsp;million) primarily due to the borrowings under the Company's revolving credit facilities. Earnings of affiliated </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=26,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=601975,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223B.;15',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_27"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
companies decreased $97&nbsp;million, due principally to the Company no longer recognizing its share of Continental Airlines,&nbsp;Inc.'s ("Continental") earnings in 2001 following the sale of
its investment in Continental, lower earnings from W</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>ORLDSPAN </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>L.P. ("W</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>ORLDSPAN</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>") in 2001 and
Orbitz,&nbsp;LLC's loss in 2001. Other income decreased $25&nbsp;million primarily due to a $58&nbsp;million gain from the sale of a portion of Northwest's investment in priceline.com in 2000,
partially offset by a $27&nbsp;million gain recorded in 2001 on the sale of the Company's remaining investment in Continental. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had cash, cash equivalents and restricted short-term investments of $2.20&nbsp;billion. This amount
included $100&nbsp;million of restricted short-term investments, resulting in total liquidity of $2.10&nbsp;billion, a decrease in liquidity of $414&nbsp;million from
December&nbsp;31, 2001. As discussed later, the Company's secured credit facilities were fully drawn as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 and had $1&nbsp;million available as of December&nbsp;31,
2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
used in operating activities was $284&nbsp;million in 2002. Cash flows provided by operating activities were $646&nbsp;million in 2001 and $893&nbsp;million in 2000. The
decrease of $930&nbsp;million in operating cash flows from 2001 was primarily due to $410&nbsp;million of cash received under the Airline Stabilization Act grant in 2001, the January&nbsp;2002
disbursement of $216&nbsp;million of aviation taxes originally due between September&nbsp;11, 2001 and January&nbsp;15, 2002, but deferred pursuant to federal authorization, a
$108&nbsp;million increase in the Company's income tax refund receivable and a decrease in the air traffic liability. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company operates, like its competitors, with negative working capital, which aggregated $762&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002. This position is primarily attributable to
the $1.22&nbsp;billion air traffic liability, largely representing cash received from tickets that customers have purchased in advance and not yet used. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing activities consist primarily of the purchase of aircraft and other related costs including
engine purchases, costs to commission aircraft before entering revenue service, deposits on ordered aircraft, facility improvements and ground equipment purchases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities consisted of the acquisition of the following aircraft for the years ended December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="71%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities in 2002 other than aircraft purchases include facilities and aircraft modification programs. Investing activities in 2001 other than aircraft purchases include
$582&nbsp;million in proceeds from the sale of the Company's investment in Continental. See Note&nbsp;13 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional discussion of the Company's
investment in Continental. Investing activities in 2000 other than aircraft purchases include $58&nbsp;million of proceeds from the sale of a portion of the Company's investment in priceline.com. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=27,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=606284,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223B.;15',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1223_1_28"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the purchased aircraft shown in the above table, the Company also took delivery of 21 Bombardier CRJ200/440 regional jets in each of 2002 and 2001 and nine CRJ200 regional
jets in 2000. These aircraft were financed with long-term leveraged operating leases provided by the manufacturer and were simultaneously subleased to Pinnacle Airlines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing activities in 2002 consisted primarily of the issuance of $300&nbsp;million of 9.875%
public unsecured notes due in 2007, the payment of debt and capital lease obligations, and the financing of: (i)&nbsp;18 Airbus A319 aircraft, one Boeing 747-400 aircraft, two Airbus
A320 aircraft and three Boeing 757-300 aircraft with escrowed funds from pass-through certificate offerings issued in 2001; (ii)&nbsp;two Boeing 757-300 aircraft
with escrowed funds from pass-through certificate offerings issued in 2002; (iii)&nbsp;three Boeing 757-200 aircraft, two Boeing 757-300 aircraft and six Airbus
A319 aircraft with long-term bank debt; (iv)&nbsp;one Boeing 747-400 under a sale and leaseback; and the refinancing of three Boeing 747-400 aircraft purchased
off capital lease. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
August&nbsp;2002, the Company completed an offering of $749&nbsp;million of pass-through certificates to finance or refinance the acquisition of 11 new Airbus A319
aircraft, six new Boeing 757-300 aircraft and three new Airbus A330 aircraft scheduled to be delivered between October&nbsp;2002 and December&nbsp;2003. The pre-funded
portion of cash proceeds from the offerings of certificates are invested and held in escrow with a depositary bank. Such funds are not assets or direct obligations of, or guaranteed by, the Company
and are therefore not included in the Consolidated Financial Statements. As aircraft are delivered or refinanced, the Company utilizes the cash proceeds to finance the acquisition of these aircraft as
secured debt financing for ownership or as non-recourse debt for leveraged lease financing. If a leveraged lease is obtained for any aircraft, under which the aircraft would be sold and
leased back to Northwest, the debt associated with the aircraft will become part of the lease and not a direct obligation of the Company or Northwest. Lease obligations that qualify as operating
leases under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;13 are disclosed in Note&nbsp;4 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. If any funds remain as deposits with the escrow
agent for pass-through certificates at the end of the delivery period, such funds will be distributed back to the certificate holders, including interest on such amounts payable by the
Company. Management believes that the likelihood funds would be distributed from escrow back to investors and that the interest due would be a material amount is remote. As of December&nbsp;31,
2002, $668&nbsp;million of the unused offering proceeds were held in escrow to finance a portion of the aircraft scheduled for delivery in 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing
activities in 2001 consisted primarily of the Company's borrowing in March and subsequent repayment in May of $1.10&nbsp;billion under its revolving credit facilities, the
borrowing on September&nbsp;11, 2001, of $1.12&nbsp;billion under its revolving credit facilities, of which $150&nbsp;million was repaid in October&nbsp;2001 as scheduled, the issuance of
$300&nbsp;million of 8.875% public unsecured notes due 2006, $120&nbsp;million received under airport facility revenue bonds and payment of debt and capital lease obligations. Financing activities
also included the receipt of $678&nbsp;million in financing for: (i)&nbsp;13 Airbus A319 aircraft, seven of which were financed with funds from pass-through certificates and six with
long-term bank debt; (ii)&nbsp;five Boeing 757-200 aircraft financed with long-term bank debt; and (iii)&nbsp;four Airbus A320 aircraft, three of which were
financed with funds from pass-through certificates and one with long-term bank debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2001, the Company completed a pre-funded offering of $581&nbsp;million of pass-through certificates at a blended fixed coupon rate of 7.18%.
Proceeds from sales of the certificates were used to finance the
acquisition of 14 aircraft consisting of nine new Airbus A319 aircraft, three new Boeing 757-300 aircraft and two new Boeing 747-400 aircraft delivered between March and
December&nbsp;2002. In July&nbsp;2001, the Company completed an offering of $396&nbsp;million of European pass-through certificates due in 2013 at a blended floating rate of
three-month London Interbank Offered Rate ("LIBOR") plus 0.60% (2.23% as of December&nbsp;31, 2002) to finance the acquisition of nine new Airbus A319 aircraft and five new Airbus A320 aircraft
delivered between November&nbsp;2001 and July&nbsp;2002. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=28,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=401137,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DK1223B.;15',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;21:25' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm1223_1_29"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing activities in 2000 consisted primarily of payment of debt and capital lease obligations, including $165&nbsp;million in term loan prepayments, and the long-term
leveraged operating lease financing through sale and leaseback of ten Airbus A319 aircraft and three AVRO RJ85 aircraft. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2000, the Company completed a public offering totaling $522&nbsp;million of pass-through certificates to finance the acquisition of 13 new aircraft delivered in 2000
and 2001 and to refinance six other aircraft delivered in 1996. </FONT></P>

lease payments, aircraft purchases and certain other obligations for the years ending December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent principal payments only. The amount due in 2005 includes $962&nbsp;million of principal outstanding on the Company's bank revolving credit facilities. See
Note&nbsp;3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional discussion of long-term debt and future maturities.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent principal payments only. See Note&nbsp;4 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional discussion of capital leases.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent minimum lease payments with initial or remaining terms of more than one year and exclude related sublease rental income. See Note&nbsp;4 to the Consolidated
Financial Statements for additional discussion of operating leases.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
include expenditures for aircraft and related equipment, including estimates for contracted price escalations and predelivery deposits. The Company's firm orders for 62 new
aircraft to be operated by Northwest consist of scheduled deliveries for 14 Airbus A330-300 aircraft from 2003 through 2008, ten Airbus A330-200 aircraft from 2004 through
2008, eight Airbus A320 aircraft from 2003 through 2006, 21 Airbus A319 aircraft from 2003 through 2006, and nine Boeing 757-300 aircraft in 2003. Included in these firm orders are two
Airbus A320 and four Airbus A319 aircraft scheduled for delivery in 2004 and 2005, which were converted from options to firm orders in the first quarter of 2002. Financing commitments available for
use by the Company are in place for all of the aircraft on order. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company also had firm orders for 78 Bombardier CRJ200/440 aircraft, 44 of which will be subleased
to Pinnacle Airlines. The balance of the CRJ aircraft have not been committed to any carrier. The Company has the option to finance the CRJ200/440 aircraft through long-term operating
lease commitments from the manufacturer, and if the manufacturer does not provide the financing, the Company is not required to take delivery of the aircraft.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(5)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>See
Note&nbsp;6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional discussion of the Company's obligations related to the Series&nbsp;C preferred stock. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Funding Obligations.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has several noncontributory pension plans covering substantially all of its
employees. Funding obligations under these plans are governed by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA"). As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company's pension plans were
underfunded by $3.95&nbsp;billion as calculated in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87. Also, as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, on a current liability basis utilized for cash contribution purposes, the
plans were underfunded by approximately $3.1&nbsp;billion. The Company's 2003 pension contributions associated with the 2003 plan year are estimated to be $468&nbsp;million. The Company also had,
as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, $223&nbsp;million of mandatory contributions related to the 2002 plan year remaining to be paid in 2003. Pension funding requirements are dependent upon various
factors, including interest rate levels, asset returns, regulatory requirements for funding purposes and changes to pension plan benefits. Absent favorable changes to these factors, the Company will
have to satisfy the underfunded amounts of its plans through cash contributions over time. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;5, 2002, the Company submitted an application to the Internal Revenue Service for authorization to reschedule 2003 plan year contributions required under the pension
plans for contract and salaried employees. This application, if approved, could allow the Company to defer some or all of the $468&nbsp;million in 2003 plan year contributions due in calendar 2003.
The Company anticipates receiving notice from the Internal Revenue Service by April&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has also submitted an application to the Department of Labor to permit the Company to contribute common stock of Pinnacle Airlines Corp. to the pension plans in lieu of
making certain required contributions in cash. In January&nbsp;2003, the Department of Labor issued a proposed prohibited transaction exemption that would allow the Company to contribute common
stock of Pinnacle Airlines Corp. to satisfy a portion of the contribution requirements to Northwest's pension plans in 2003 and 2004. The proposed prohibited transaction exemption contemplates that
the pension plans will have the right at any time to sell the shares back to the Company for cash at the greater of the original purchase price or the then market value. Pinnacle Airlines Corp. was
incorporated in Delaware on January&nbsp;10, 2002 for the sole purpose of becoming a holding company of Pinnacle Airlines. Prior to the contribution, the Company transferred all of the outstanding
stock of Pinnacle Airlines to Pinnacle Airlines Corp. in exchange for all of the outstanding common stock of Pinnacle Airlines Corp. and one share of Series&nbsp;A preferred stock of Pinnacle
Airlines Corp. The Company then contributed 1.9&nbsp;million shares, or 12.9%, of the Pinnacle Airlines Corp. common stock to the pension plan to satisfy approximately $44&nbsp;million of its
$223&nbsp;million scheduled funding requirement for the 2002 plan year. In lieu of making cash contributions, the Company intends to contribute additional common stock of Pinnacle Airlines Corp. to
satisfy a portion of future mandatory pension contributions, including the remainder of 2002 plan year requirements. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Ratings.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company's Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's corporate credit rating and its senior
unsecured credit rating were BB- and B, respectively; its Moody's Investor Services senior implied rating and senior unsecured rating were B1 and B2, respectively; and its Fitch Ratings
senior unsecured credit rating was B+. The lowering of the Company's credit ratings could make it more difficult to issue debt, to renew outstanding letters of credit that back certain obligations and
to obtain financial instruments used in its fuel and currency hedging programs, as well as to potentially increase the cost of these transactions. For information regarding the impact from the
lowering of the Company's secured credit facility credit rating on June&nbsp;28, 2002, see the related discussion below as well as Note&nbsp;3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. For
information regarding the Company's receivables purchase agreement and the credit rating requirements of this agreement, see Note&nbsp;13 to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=30,EFW="2105681",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=949436,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK030:[03STP3.03STP1223]DM1223A.;12',USER='JGARCEA',CD='18-MAR-2003;17:51' -->
